Award.AwardTitle: Electroweak and Strong Interactions at Very High Energies: Precision Tests of the Standard Model and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Doreen Wackeroth at the University at Buffalo, The State University of New York.

Particle physics research has entered an exciting era: The CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is successfully colliding proton beams at energies that allow for the exploration of matter and the laws of physics that govern its properties at the most fundamental level. Despite the enormous success of the Standard Model (SM) in describing all experimentally observed electromagnetic, weak, and strong interactions of the constituents of matter, it is generally accepted that the SM is merely a low-energy approximation to a more fundamental theory which is expected to reveal itself at the LHC in form of the emergence of new, non-SM particles and interactions. Moreover, there is still one prediction of the SM that awaits experimental confirmation: the existence of a Higgs particle, which is thought to be associated with the observed phenonenon of electroweak symmetry breaking. If the SM Higgs boson exists, it will not escape detection at the LHC. However, in order to extract meaningful information from LHC data, the theoretical predictions for relevant LHC processes must be of a precision that exceeds anticipated experimental precision. This project will therefore consist of improving the current predictions for such processes. Specifically, the PI will perform calculations of cross sections at higher orders in perturbation theory and implement these improved calculations in Monte Carlo programs.

This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. The proposed calculations are challenging and will provide the graduate students involved with an advanced research experience and with skills valuable beyond the scope of particle-physics research. These research activities will be pursued in collaboration with scientists worldwide, and will further US-international joint scientific efforts. The PI will also continue to organize activities involving the Physics Department's Physics & Arts Exhibition, which aims to convey the excitement of fundamental research to K-12 and undergraduate students as well as to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Principle Investigator of this award is conducting research in high-energy particle physics, a field of physics that is concerned with exploring and understanding the physical world at its most fundamental level through high-energy collider experiments, such as the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The observations made at the LHC and their interpretations provide insight into the strong and electroweak interactions of the constituents of matter, lepton and quarks, of particles mediating these fundamental interactions, photons, W, Z bosons and gluons, and, since recently, also of the Higgs boson. With the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 at the LHC, the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics is now complete, and so far all experimental results have been found to be in agreement with the predictions of the SM. However, the LHC is operating at a new energy and precision frontier and for the first time in the history of particle physics since the introduction of the SM, we are searching only for truly new and unexpected signals of unknown physics. To be able to make such a discovery, predictions for SM processes have to be under superb theoretical control, at least at the level of the experimental precision. This involves highly complex calculations in Quantum Field Theory and their implementation in Monte Carlo (MC) simulation programs to be able to compare with LHC measurements. As a result of this award the predictions for a number of SM processes have been considerably improved and new avenues for testing new physics scenarios at the LHC have been explored. The MC tools developed for this award have been made publicly available and are being used by the experimental high-energy physics community to aide in the full exploitation of the potential of the LHC for testing the SM at an increasingly high level of precision and for searching for signals of new physics. Examples of SM processes under consideration are the production of a Higgs boson in association with heavy quarks (top and bottom quarks), single W and Z boson production, top-pair and di-jet production. The improved calculations have been made available in the public MC codes POWHEG (Higgs in association with heavy quarks), MCFM (weak corrections to top-pair, Z boson and di-jet production), and in WZGRAD (W and Z boson production).  These improvements were necessary for the extraction of the coupling of the Higgs boson to heavy quarks, which will further our understanding of the nature of this newly discovered particle, for a new measurement of the W boson mass at the LHC, which is a sensitive probe of indirect effects of new physics, and for the search of direct signals of new physics in the tails of kinematic distributions of SM processes. The new physics scenarios, whose potential for detection at the LHC have been explored as part of this award, are the CP violating minimal supersymmetric extensions of the SM (MSSM) and the Peccei-Quinn-augmented MSSM, which features three valid dark matter candidates. Last but not least, this award provided an excellent training ground for two graduate students and three undergraduate students, who respectively moved on to careers in particle physics or data science and to graduate school.
